title._content: Mary Jane Nee, Assistant Manager of Visitor Services

description._content: Where are you originally from? Santa Cruz, California. What do you do here? I manage the admissions desk in the lobby. In a broader sense, I act as an advocate for the visitor and uphold our mission of being the most visitor-friendly museum. What is the funniest or most interesting experience you've had while working here? Probably the funniest, and most bizarre, thing I've done was at the closing of ©MURAKAMI. It was a really long and intensive exhibition in terms of the crowds so, as a reward, I promised my staff I would gallop around the Visitors Center on my toy pony. So after we made our last ticket sales, I hopped on the pony and did several rounds while making horse noises, much to the amusement of my staff (and myself). What's your favorite work of art at the Museum? Georgia O'Keefe's Green, Yellow, and Orange. What's your commute like? It's a pleasant walk through Prospect Park. In the summer I even take off my shoes and walk through the grass (Hey, I'm from California . . .). What was your last job before the Museum? I was a manager at J. Crew. What did you want to be when you grew up? A pet psychologist. Do you have any hidden talents? I'm actually an excellent packer. In fact, I practice pack: I fully pack my suitcase, then take everything out, so I can finalize what I'm actually going to take. And when I'm in the security line at the airport, I always have a game plan prepared for getting through as quickly as possible. It's something akin to George Clooney's character in Up in the Air.
